name: clonazepam
Reason: The compound clonazepam consists of several functional groups and structural features which impact its melting point. The base structure includes two benzenes, and as such we can use biphenyl as a starting reference, which has a melting point of around 70 °C. The first benzene ring contains a chlorine substituent, and chloro groups tend to increase the melting point. The general effect of a chloro group on the melting point can be estimated at around +20 °C due to increased molecular weight and polarity. The second benzene ring is part of a benzodiazepine core, which involves nitrogen atoms in a heterocyclic system, typically increasing the melting point due to additional ring stability, and potential for hydrogen bonding. An amide functional group is attached to this core, which can have a large influence on the melting point, potentially adding another +80 °C due to strong intermolecular hydrogen bonding and resonance stability of the amide linkage. A nitro group is also attached to the first benzene ring, which is electron-withdrawing and can increase the melting point possibly by another +30 °C given its strong inductive effect and impact on molecular stability.
